1103733867670892549.text:
How much decentralization can your PoS network afford?

Say cost to run node is $1.5k/yr

100 nodes = $150k
1k nodes = $1.5m
100k nodes = $150m
1m nodes = $1.5b

To afford 1m independent nodes at 5% issuance you need mkt cap of $30b just to cover h/w

Decentralization ain't cheap

1124447622847033344.text: In addition since the only "wealth" these accounts hold is trust, and that too for time limited periods there is less incentive for violent theft of keys

1124447343137308673.text: I think the contracts for this sort of system could be thrown together without too much effort. If bootstrapped carefully, it could serve as a voting system for other projects. The lack of token means it is harder for wealthy groups to capture voting automatically

1124447027704635392.text: In some ways, this system is similar to Proof of Stake systems, but the difference is that there is no token. Rewards are increased trust for set periods of time. Punishments are decreased trust for set periods of time.

1124446757801189377.text: In addition, to lower the chance of puppet accounts proliferating, any identity holder is allowed to accuse another of being a bot. If the vote agrees with this accusation, the attesters of this account are punished. The accuser gains the ability to attest for more people

1124446254849617920.text: Let's say that for confirmation, a new identity with 5 attestations is voted on by the set of all identities. The twist here is that if the vote goes against you, the 5 attesters lose their vote for a set period of time.

1124445963609825280.text: The major danger here is sybil attacks. Can I make 50 puppet accounts under my control? If I get 5 friends, we could form a trust cartel that prints new identities and tips votes in our favor. How can we prevent this? We need to bring stake back in somehow

1124445571282903040.text: Let's say that for me to gain a identity, I need to be attested for by 5 trustworthy individuals. Once I hav an identity, I can attest for others as well. Each identity is given one and only one vote. If the core network is grown out carefully, identities could be sound

1124444927088193536.text: In a staked voting system, my vote is proportional to my staked funds. So if I staked all 10 ETH, my vote would be 10x that of someone with 1 ETH. This creates the rule by wealthy we saw above with Aragon. Instead of vote weighting, let's introduce a new idea of trust weighting

1124444536409714688.text: We don't yet have institutions like banks or credit card companies with long histories on Ethereum. But we can reuse funds with wealth to help bootstrap the identity network. Let's suppose I hold an Ethereum address with funds. Let's say 10 ETH to be precise

1124444043188948994.text: A few people have suggested networks of social trust could serve as identity. This is how governmental agencies verify identity. The DMV requires bank statements or credit card statements to verify identity for example. They believe these companies attest for you

1124443732072288256.text: Remember in crypto revealing that you hold large amounts of funds is a literal security hazard. There have been attacks on people to steal private keys for funds. Ideally a voting system shouldn't be tied to proof of wealth in this way

1124443447035715584.text: There's a second danger in tying identity to accounts with funds. You are making it easier to identify who's behind those accounts (you can gauge proclivities of the true owner from the voting record). Chain analysis tools might be able to identify the owner

1124443155724529664.text: This means wealthy accounts can quite literally tip elections in their favor by using their wealth. See this recent analysis of votes on Aragon for a literal example of thishttps://www.evanvanness.com/post/184616403861/aragon-vote-shows-the-perils-of-onchain-governance/ …

1124442879928045568.text: Here's a crude proposal for an identity system on top of Ethereum. At present Ethereum identity is tied to accounts that hold stake (funds). This prevents Sybil attacks where networks of bots tip votes in their favor. But it favors "whales" who own lots of funds

1120837469748862976.text: Debt is an old and understood instrument. Income sharing agreements are new and unregulated and untested. 1120500697353588738.text: We don't allow legislation to be passed by the developers of .gov websites. Similarly, blockchain devs shouldn't be able to unilaterally pass  what amounts to crypto legislation. They can participate of course, but other voices must be heard

1120500188873920513.text: This pushback is not toxic. Rather it is healthy. Technical considerations cannot decide policy. They can inform policy, but not decide it. Consider the equivalent of allowing the fed to be run by the developers of SWIFT standards. It's two different skill sets

1120499856651489280.text: Ethereum developer forums often ban non technical discussion. This leads to the presentation of political decisions as fait accompli at times. The ProgPOW and Block Rewards issues fall in this camp. Strong public pushback results

1120499538945564672.text: As others have suggested, Ethereum needs a political process. Developers shouldn't be the only voices making critical policy decisions. Other stakeholders should be equally valued.

1120499191976026114.text: This is a fascinating thread on the governance debates rocking the Ethereum ecosystem. The core debate is whether the blockchain itself should fund developers via block rewards. I'm against this type of funding personallyhttps://twitter.com/scott_lew_is/status/1120093065954385920 …

1120498141894270977.text: Large corporations have outsourced risk to startups for decades and decades. Big chains should similarly outsource risk to small chains

1120498000193839105.text: Enabling block rewards could speed development but destroy ETH's monetary value. I'd much rather ETH become better money and slowly adopt innovations from smaller chains as they debug basic concepts. Risk can be outsourced to smaller projects

1120497751047983108.text: It's not enough to just build a fast distributed computer. The magic of Ethereum is that it is Turing Complete money. This means that any system that works with money can be built on Ethereum. Companies, foundations, governments even. But this needs ETH to be money

1120497377721319425.text: Block Rewards for development allows for the possibility of developer fund misuse. I'd much rather wait until DAOs have been battle tested with large funds of money (in the tens of millions) and chains like Tezos have stabilized on-chain governance

1120497050641104897.text: I'd much rather have Ethereum follow Bitcoin's policy of attempting to build a solid monetary foundation by becoming a reserve currency. Most decentralized finance protocols only work if ETH is globally recognized as a valuable asset.

1120496609102528513.text: I'm tentatively against block rewards for development in Ethereum. The Ethereum foundation has not yet shown good transparency in their grant approval process. 1079296472846262272.text: Take the modulus by x^n basically truncates. This is equivalent to setting 1/10^n = 0, which is a truncation at the n-th digit. This structure is a ring for sure, but it's not a field. I'm not sure if this is the best possible approximation though

1079296038073118721.text: I think a reasonable model might be (Z/p)[x]/x^n. Why does this make sense. Suppose x=1/beta, where beta is the floating point base. For example, x=1/10. Then a polynomial in (Z/p)[x] could be interpreted as a polynomial in powers or 1/10, which is exactly a decimal.

1079289046868742145.text: I know of things like logarithmic number systems which have nice properties, but I'm not sure if they form nice algebraic structures like a domain

1075807350408151040.text: So it follows that Q/p has size p. All finite fields of a given size are isomorphic, so Q/p is isomorphic to Z/p! I don't yet know the structure of this isomorphism though. Something to dig up another day

1075806851617325056.text: The equivalence relation can only shrink the size of the set. Since we know Q/p contains a copy of Z/p as the tuples (a, 1) it has size at least p. But Q/p is a finite field which must have size q^n. It contains a subfield of size p, which means q=2. We know n < 2

1075806258047766528.text: When constructing the field of fractions of Z/p, you start with the tuples in Z/p x (Z/p - {0}). You then use the equivalence relation (a, b) ~ (c, d) when ad = cb to factor down. So Q/p = Z/p x (Z/p - {0}) / ~. This has size at most p*(p-1)

1075805608954089472.text: The story deepens. It turns out with some thought that Q/p is actually isomorphic to Z/p, so my original intuition wasn't too far off! The only finite fields it turns out are those of size q^2, where q is any prime
